User manual for &app;

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The &app; GNOME panel applet downloads current stock quotes from Yahoo! Finance and displays the quotes in a drop-down list.
&app; displays the following information for each stock symbol that is defined in the applet preferences:

listitem.para: The stock symbol that represents a company
The current share price quote (delayed 15 minutes)
The change in the stock price over the last day.
The amount of the increase or decrease in the price since purchase
The percentage increase or decrease in the price since purchase

sect2.title: Add &app; to a Panel
sect2.para: To add &app; to a GNOME panel, right-click on the panel, then choose Add to Panel. Select &app; in the Add to Panel dialog, then click OK. Click Close when finished.

sect2.title: Remove &app; From a Panel
sect2.para: To remove &app; from a GNOME panel, right-click on the icon, then choose Remove From Panel.

sect2.title: More Information
sect2.para: More information about the GNOME panel can be found in the GNOME Panel documentation.

sect2.title: Add Company Stock Quotes to the Applet
sect2.para: To add stock symbols to &app;, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Right-click on the icon, and select Preferences.
Click Add to add a stock to &app;.
The default stock symbol is GOOG. Double-click the stock symbol to change the listing.
You can also edit the number of shares you own in the stock, the purchase price and the commission.
Click Close when you are finished adding stock symbols.

sect2.title: View Selected Stocks
sect2.para: To view your selected stocks, click on the &app; icon on the panel. A list of your stocks will appear. To close the list, click the icon again.

sect2.title: Update the Display
sect2.para: To immediately update the information that is displayed in the applet, right-click on the applet, then choose Refresh.

sect2.title: Remove Company Stock Quotes from the Applet
sect2.para: To remove stock symbols from &app;, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Right-click on the icon, and select Preferences.
Click the row containing the ticker symbol you wish to remove.
Click Remove to delete the listing.
Click Close when you are finished.

sect2.title: Chart Options
sect2.para: To use the financial charts, view the list of selected stocks, and double-click the stock that you wish to chart. The chart parameters can be customized by clicking Options.

sect3.title: Date Range
sect3.para: The date range, in the top-right corner of the window, selects the length of time to report on. By default it gives one day of data, but it can be extended out to three years.

sect3.title: Graph Style
sect3.para: Historical price information can be graphed in three different ways. You can select a line chart, bar chart, or candlestick chart.

listitem.para: This is the default option. This graphs the historical price information in a familiar manner, connecting each day's closing price in a with a single line for each stock. Line charts for graphing stock prices are useful if an analyst is interested only in a share's closing price each time.

A bar chart represents a full day's activity with a single vertical bar.Tthe top of the vertical line indicates the highest price a security traded at during the day, and the bottom represents the lowest price. The closing price is displayed on the right side of the bar, and the opening price is shown on the left side of the bar. One bar represents one day of trading.

A bar chart in which the open and close prices are represented as the top and bottom of a rectangle surrounding a vertical line connecting the high and low prices. The body of the rectangle is filled if the closing price is lower than the opening price and is left blank if the closing price is higher than the opening price.

sect3.title: Moving Average
sect3.para: A moving average is a statistical series of a security's closing prices throughout consecutive trading days. It is typically shown in the same graph as a line chart to indicate trends in share prices.

sect3.title: Exponential Moving Average
sect3.para: The exponential moving average (EMA) is defined as a moving average calculated by weighting recent values more heavily than older values. This type of moving average reacts faster to recent price changes than a simple moving average. The 12- and 26-day EMAs are popular short-term averages, while EMAs greater than 50 days are used to signal long-term trends.

sect3.title: Overlays
sect3.para: Overlays allow you to graph multiple statistical measurements onto a single chart. For example, you can compare the performance of a single stock against that of an index such as the NASDAQ or the DJIA.

sect3.title: Indicators
sect3.para: Indicators are used to attempt to predict future financial trends. Proper use of market indicators is beyond the scope of the Invest manual.
